Lavrientieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Graphical abstract A detailed kinetic model for formic acid (HCOOH) decomposition on oxide vanadium-titanium (7.3%V2O5/92.7%TiO2) catalyst has been developed based on transient kinetic studies and IR spectroscopy in situ. Formic acid decomposition to CO2 (dehydrogenation) and to CO (dehydration) proceeds via different mechanistic routes. Dehydrogenation proceeds via the conventional “formate” mechanism and include reversible dissociative adsorption of formic acid on vanadyl group V=O. The oxygen of the group acts as a proton acceptor whereas a vanadium cation is a formate anion stabilizer. Formate complexes can recombinate with protons and desorb in the form of formic acid or decompose to CO2. Dehydration reaction follows a different mechanism. An interaction of the coordination unsaturated sites V+-O− with HCOOH leads to the synchronous cleavage of the COH and CH bonds. Meanwhile the two OH hydroxyl groups are formed and CO molecule is evolved into gas phase. The path is completed by water desorption. The rate constants and activation energies of elementary steps are calculated for a dehydrogenation and dehydration reactions. The rate-limited steps of the reaction are formate decomposition stage for dehydrogenation path (Ea =60kJ/mol) and water desorption stage for dehydration rout (Ea =100kJ/mol). The difference in the values of activation energies results in an increase of selectivity towards CO with reaction temperature elevation. Water inhibits formic acid decomposition. In the case the dehydrogenation, it connected with adsorption displacement of formates with water, whereas, in the case of dehydration, it is associated with an active centers blocking by adsorbed water. The developed kinetic model takes into account the water effect of both routs and satisfactorily describes the steady state reaction behavior. Keywords V-Ti oxide catalyst Formic acid decomposition Transient kinetic IR spectroscopy 1 Introduction Formic acid decomposition reaction is of interest mostly as the source of alternative fuel as system HCOOH→ÑО2 +Н2 [1,2] and method for processing industrial wastes, resulting from organics oxidation, where formic acid is an often observed side product [3]. On the other hand, formic acid is a valuable product that is most widely used as a preservative and antibacterial agent for animal forage, in the coloring and finishing of fabrics, leather tanning, nickel plating and the electroplating and in the production of varnishes, glass, vinyl plasticizers. Formic acid is used in the synthesis of many organic products (including pentaerythritol and aspartame) and in the inorganic synthesis of certain metal salts [4,5]. The catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde is one of the methods for formic acid production [6–8]. In this case, the formic acid decomposition is undesired side reaction. To increase the efficiency of this process it is necessary to know the mechanism and kinetics of the HCOOH decomposition reaction. Catalytic decomposition of formic acid goes via two routs: HCOOH → CO+H 2 O dehydration HCOOH → CO 2 +H 2 d e h y d r o g e n a t i o n Many reported studies focus on the chemical nature of reaction intermediates, ways of their conversion into СО or СО2 and elementary stages kinetics. Most of these studies have been performed with metal catalysts of various composition and structure, i.e. bulk [9], supported [10–12], single crystal [13–15], metal organic complexes [16,17] and metal salts [18]. One can hardly reveal some general regularity for metal catalysts in whole. It is widely accepted that reaction mechanism should be considered independently for each group or family of catalysts. Noble metals are stated to catalyze mainly dehydrogenation, while base metals and oxides are known to catalyze both routes, either directly or via subsequent water-gas shift reaction (WGS) [10]. Dehydrogenation on noble metals goes through intermediate formate complexes [11,13]. According to Silbaugh at al [12] monodentate formate is the key intermediate of formic acid dehydrogenation on Pt. Monodentate formate converts to bidentate formate (and vice versa) to reestablish equilibrium. Herron et al. [14] present a thermochemical analysis of formic acid decomposition on model facets of Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, Pd, Ni, Rh, Co, Os, Ru, and Re metals. Density functional theory has been used to examine formic acid decomposition via “formate” (through surface HCOO* intermediates) and “carboxyl” (surface COOH* intermediate) mechanisms. After HCOOH adsorption at dehydrogenation stage either CH bond (forming COOH*) or OH bond (forming HCOO*) is broken. Next stage is the cleavage of remaining proton and СО2 evolution. Tang et al. [9] have systemized and analyzed bulk metal catalysts activity in target reaction, considering metal surface composition, number of catalytic active sites, nature of surface intermediate, HCOOH adsorption equilibrium, DFT thermal dynamics and specific steady-state reaction rates. All metal catalysts appear to provide formation of both CO2 and CO, hypothetically both dehydrogenation and dehydration proceed via decomposition of surface HCOO* species. According to TD-DRIFTS surface HCOO* is a bidentate or monodentate surface formate dependently on metal type. No CO2/CO ratio correlation with surface formate nature has been observed. Surface HCOO* decomposition rate decreases in series Pt>Cu>Pd>Co>Au>Ni >Ag>Fe>Rh and poorly correlates with steady-state TOF values. According to reference literature less research attention is paid to formic acid decomposition on oxide catalysts. Formic acid dehydrogenation mechanism has been studied by Noto at all over zinc oxide and magnesium oxide [18]. Using adsorption and IR methods authors have identified surface formate and water. Decomposition was considered to proceed as follows: at first surface formate ion is formed, and carbon dioxide evolves via formate ion decomposition on the surface. Hydrogen atom remaining on the surface is then attacked by another formic acid molecule to produce molecular hydrogen, formate ion being left on the surface. In early review Trillo et al. [19] considers the mechanism of formic acid decomposition on MgO, ZnO, oxides of 3d metals, A12O3 and SiO2. MgO and ZnO are reported to be active mainly in formic acid dehydrogenation, while A12O3 and SiO2 participate mostly in dehydration, 3d oxides showing activity in both reactions. Dehydrogenating power increases with oxide basicity. Many factors are discussed such as active site nature (Broensted sites, cations or lattice oxygen), key intermediates (formate complexes or adsorbed formic acid) and limiting reaction stage. Reaction mechanism is assumed to change with reaction temperature: at low temperatures, formic acid decomposes at adsorption on Broensted sites. At high temperatures, decomposition involves formate linked to metal cation. The authors consider the existence of specific surface sites for dehydration and dehydrogenation, but both reactions proceed through the same intermediate, i.e., surface formate species. High temperature dehydration via formate intermediate is discussed. Dehydrogenation mechanism is not analyzed in detail, though formate is considered to be intermediate in this reaction as well. Formate mechanism is also discussed in [20]. Mamoru [21], studying formic acid decomposition on various oxides, has concluded that reaction selectivity depends on acid-base properties of these oxides: activity in dehydration correlates with acidity, while that in oxidative dehydrogenation correlates with basicity. Reaction direction (dehydrogenation or dehydration) is mostly dependent on formic acid activation. At dehydrogenation formic acid may be activated by proton transfer onto a basic site, e.g., catalyst lattice oxygen O2−, yielding formate ion then stabilized on metal cation adjacent to O2−. At dehydration formic acid may be activated on catalyst acid site probably by electron transfer from formic acid onto acidic sites, i.e., via H distraction from acid or by surface proton addition to acid. Few reference data are related to formic acid decomposition on vanadia-titania catalysts (V2O5/TiO2). Reaction rate is known to increase with temperature growth, and so does the selectivity towards CO. IR spectroscopy in situ has shown that surface formates are the main products of formic acid adsorption [22]. A simplified kinetic scheme has been suggested [23], including reversible stage of formic acid adsorption with proton cleavage and formates formation, followed by formates decomposition to carbon oxides (no details related to dehydration and dehydrogenation being included). Basing on DFT calculations Avdeev and Parmon [24] have suggested the following mechanism of formic acid decomposition on V2O5/TiO2. At first dissociative adsorption of HCOOH through oxygen lone pair electrons of CO carbonyl group produces surface monodentate formates and V-OH Broensted acid sites leading to dehydrogenation products CO2 +H2. The proposed dehydrogenation path complies with the “formate mechanism”. Dehydration is initiated by HCOOH adsorption by the oxygen of COH hydroxyl group, followed by synchronous formation of hydroxylated surface and CO evolution into the gas phase. This path is completed by recombination of two VOH surface hydroxyl groups yielding adsorbed H2O, no formate species being involved. Therefore, on metal and oxide catalysts dehydrogenation is believed to go via the “formate mechanism”. As for dehydration reaction there exist different points of view: (a) dehydration also proceeds via the “formate mechanism”, (b) unlike dehydrogenation dehydration goes via another mechanism, but both reactions may proceed on the same surface sites, (c) dehydration occurs without formates participation on other surface sites, (d) dehydration and dehydrogenation may occur on different sites, but same intermediates may be involved. According to [25] water vapor addition into reaction mixture decreases formic acid decomposition rate and reaction selectivity towards CO. We assume that water effect studies (especially under unsteady state conditions) may give the key to reaction mechanism understanding and help the adequate kinetic model development. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst Oxide vanadia-titania catalyst 7.3%V2O5/92.7%TiO2 (wt%) was obtained via anatase titanium dioxide impregnation with a calculated amount of vanadyl oxalate (VOC2O4) solution. Paste was then dried in air at 110°С for 12h and calcined at 450°С for 4h. Catalyst specific surface was Ssp =54m2/g. According to X-ray phase analysis and IR spectroscopy catalyst is comprised by anatase TiO2. Vanadium surface density is 8.9×1018 atoms per m2, which was close to a monolayer coverage [26]. Powder XRD patterns were obtained using a Siemens D500 diffractometer (Germany) with the monochromated Cu Kα radiation. IR spectra were collected using a FTIR spectrometer BOMEM MB-102 (Canada). To measure the spectra, the samples were pretreated by the pelletizing with CsI (1.5mg of the sample and 500mg of CsI). The Fig. 1 represents XRD patterns (a) and IR spectra of TiO2 (curve 1), the catalyst (curves 2) and V2O5 (curve 3). Only reflexes and vibrational bands of anatase are observed. The position of absent in XRD patterns reflexes of orthorhombic V2O5 is denoted by asterixes. Thus all vanadia presents on the support surface in the highly dispersed state. 2.2 Steady state kinetic experiments Experiments were performed in a flow-circuit setup under atmospheric pressure at 120°С over catalyst fraction 0.25–0.50mm, contact time, formic acid concentration and water amount being varied. Formic acid (HCOOH, purity 99%, Aldrich) and water were dozed with air flow saturated with water or formic acid at a given temperature. Chromatography analysis wad done with Zvet-500 equipped with thermal conductivity detector. СО was analyzed with column filled with molecular sieves NaA (column length 1m, d=4mm), while НСООН and СО2 were analyzed over Porapak T (column length 1m, d=3mm). Carbon balance was 97±2%. 2.3 Transient kinetic studies in a flow reactor Experiments were arranged in a flow setup with gas phase mass spectrometry analysis (gas analyzer Stanford research systems-200) via multiple ion detection (MID), i.e. mass spectrometer worked under mass selection regime. Weighted catalyst sample (0.3g) was put into a quartz tubular reactor. Before experiment catalyst sample was heated in oxygen atmosphere (15%O2 in He) at 300°C for 1h. After cooling in the same mixture at 120°C mixture 1.6%HCOOH+15%O2 in He was supplied into reactor inlet. After steady state attainment mixture was changed by flow 15%O2 in He. HCOOH concentration was determined according to peak intensities at m/e 29. СO2 and СO concentrations were determined according to m/e 44 and m/e 28, accounting for HCOOH fragments and СO2 fragment introduction to m/e 28. 2.4 In situ IR spectrometry in the flow reactor In situ IR spectroscopy studies were performed in a flow high temperature IR reactor-cell using Bomem MB-102. Catalyst tablet (1sm×3sm, mass 50mg) was put into IR cell (volume 1.5sm3). Sample was trained in air flow at 250°С for 1h. Then sample was cooled to 120°С, air was substituted by reaction mixture 1.5% НСООН in air, and IR spectra were recorded in definite time intervals until steady coverage by surface complexes was attained. Flow rate was 1cm3/s. After that reaction mixture was substituted by air flow or mixture 4% H2O in air. IR spectra resolution was 4sm−1. All spectra of surface compounds were obtained via catalyst spectra subtraction from those registered under reaction conditions. 2.5 Transient kinetic studies in closed reactor Formic acid adsorption and decomposition reactions under reduced pressure were carried out in a vacuum static setup. The setup was made of stainless steel with a small quartz reactor and was described elsewhere [27]. It was equipped with an on-line mass-spectrometer (SRS RGA 200) to analyze the gas phase composition. Reactor loaded with catalyst sample (0.6g) could be isolated from the rest of the setup. This ensured gas phase substitution in the setup at closed reactor closure. Prior to experiments, catalyst was subjected to a standard pretreatment in vacuum and then in oxygen (1Torr) at 250°C for 1h. After cooling to reaction temperature under vacuum formic acid was introduced into the system. Values m/e used in the experiments were 18 (H2O), 28 (CO), 44 (CO2), 29 (НСООН). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Steady state kinetic experiments Table 1 lists the values of CO and CO2 formation rates under steady state conditions. These values correspond to various reaction mixture compositions and temperatures. Conversion (X) and CO selectivity values are also given (S CO). According to Table 1 in this range of reaction conditions formic acid decomposition rate is weakly dependent on acid concentration but strongly depends on the water content. One can see (experiments №1 and №1a; both experiments was carried out at close to zero H2O concentrations) that the transformation rate and the selectivity vary only slightly at almost twice the change in the concentration of formic acid. On the other hand when the concentration of H2O increases in 2.5 times (experiments №2 and №3) the rate of CO decreases twice. СО2 formation rate also decreases but to less extent. This is followed by CO selectivity decrease with water content growth in the mixture. In the range of variation of H2O concentration 0–14.5%, CO formation rate decreases by 6-fold at 120°C, the selectivity toward CO decreases by 30%. When the temperature is raised up to 140°C, both the overall degradation rate of HCOOH and the selectivity toward CO are increased as compared to 120°C. The effect of water vapor at 140°C is somewhat weaker. In the range of variation of H2O concentration 0–15%, CO formation rate decreases by 4.5-fold, the selectivity toward CO decreases by about 10%. 3.2 Transient kinetic studies in the flow reactor As reaction mixture 1.5% HCOOH+15%O2 +He is supplied onto preliminarily oxidized catalyst, one may observe a long enough (more than 10min) transient period, before reaction attains steady state (see Fig. 2 a). During this period there is essential unbalance between carbon atoms at reactor inlet and outlet due to formic acid adsorption on the catalyst surface. Fig. 2b shows the curve of adsorbed formic acid complexes accumulation, calculated according to the difference between CHOOH concentration at reactor inlet and summed CHOOH+CO+CO2 concentration at reactor outlet. As reaction approaches steady state conditions, the concentration of these complexes attains 1.6×1018 mol/m2. After reaction mixture is switched to oxygen, formic acid desorbs from the catalyst surface, and carbon oxides form. During either reaction mixture or oxygen supply, СO2 concentration changes synchronously with that of adsorbed formic acid complexes. According to reference data formic acid adsorbs mainly as formate complexes. Therefore, one may assume СO2 to form via surface formates decomposition. Note, however, that integral amount of СO2, evolved after reaction mixture supply is stopped, is by an order of magnitude less than evolved formic acid amount. Therefore, the main rout of formates transformation is their recombination with protons and desorption as formic acid. CO response dynamics is completely different from that of СO2. During reaction mixture supply, there is a well expressed maximum of CO concentration. Therefore, at first CO formation rate increases (even faster than that of СO2), then passes the maximum and then decreases. What is the reason for such unordinary dehydration dynamics in transient regime is explained by experiments described in Section 3.4. Basing on above described experiment, we may only state the absence of correlation between the CO formation rate and adsorbed formic acid concentration, thus assuming that dehydration reaction does not follow the formate mechanism. 3.3 In situ IR spectroscopy in the flow reactor In the IR spectra of V/Ti oxide catalyst, registered with increasing time of 1%HCOOH in air mixture supply, one may distinguish three groups of the bands. Their intensities change independently of each other. This was the reason for their attribution to the three types of adsorbed formic acid: 1) bidentate formate ions—BF (νs(СОО)+δ(СН)=2960cm−1, ν(СН)=2883cm−1, νas(СОО)=1550 сì−1, δ(СН)=1375cm−1, νs(СОО)=1365cm−1); 2) monodentate formate ions MF (νas(СОО)=1668cm−1, νs(СОО)=1250cm−1); 3) molecularly adsorbed acid—HFA (ν(CH)=2945 cm−1, ν(CO)=1720см−1, ν(CO)=1180cm−1); After reaction mixture substitution by air or air-vapor mixture intensity of these bands decreases. Initial spectra obtained at various temperatures are discussed elsewhere [28]. Fig. 3 shows the IR spectrum of formic acid adsorbed on V/Ti oxide catalyst at 120°С. Formates formation is accompanied by the decrease of the band at 2030cm−1, related to the first overtone of stretching vibration of vanadyl group V=O. In the difference spectrum this band has negative intensity. Negative intensity of this band well correlates with the positive intensity of bands within 1668–1250cm−1, characterizing formates. Therefore, this correlation evidences for the participation of V=O sites in formates generation. Moreover, as formates form, a new wide band appears at 3270cm−1, referred to the OH stretching vibration of hydrogen bonded hydroxyl groups. Intensity of this band also correlates with that of formate bands. Intensity of band at 3650cm−1, related to the OH stretching vibration of surface catalyst hydroxyl groups, decreases in the course of formic acid adsorption (the band has negative intensity in the difference spectra). No adsorbed water is observed. This means that catalyst ОН-groups do not participate directly in formic acid dissociation, but form hydrogen bonds with all surface complexes. Therefore, dissociative adsorption of formic acid, yielding formates and hydrogen bonded hydroxyl groups, is assisted by vanadyl groups V=O, in which oxygen acts as acceptor of protons. Meanwhile additional site for formate coordination is created. Fig. 4 demonstrates time dependencies of the bands from BF (νas(COO)=1550cm−1), MF (νas(COO)=1668cm−1) and НFA ν(CO)=1720cm−1). According to the data presented in [29,30] extinction coefficient (ε) for bidentate formate complexes is about 5*10−19 cm2/molecule. Using this coefficient, we have calculated BF concentration versus time (Fig. 4а, right scale). As reaction approaches steady state, BF concentration attains 1.3*1018 molecules/m2, which is around 80% of the total amount of adsorbed formic acid, estimated during transient kinetic experiments performed under similar conditions. Remaining 20% (or 0.3*1018 molecules/m2) refer to MF and HFA. Taking into account that the shape and frequency of νas(СОО) and ν(CO) modes for MF and HFA are close, one may assume that these complexes have comparable extinction coefficients. Then, knowing the summed concentration of MF and HFA, we may approximately (with an accuracy of ±10%) correlate the scale of intensities of bands νas(СОО) and ν(CO) for these complexes with concentration scale (Fig. 4b, right scale). Same calculations have been done for temperature 140°С. Presented calculations show that more than by 90% formic acid adsorbs as formates, bidenate complex being the dominating one. As reaction mixture is supplied or switched to air or vapor-air, BF and MF concentrations change almost synchronously (this is true for temperature 140°С as well). Both type formates similarly react to the presence of water vapors in the gas phase. As reaction mixture is switched to vapor-air mixture (air+HCOOH→air+H2O), BF and MF concentrations decrease faster than in the dry flow. Formates decomposition rate growth in water presence is excluded, since it contradicts steady state experiments. Therefore, water has a positive effect on the rate of formic acid desorption. Such a synchronous change of BF and MF concentrations is most likely caused by mutual transformations BF↔MF, which as shown by DFT [24] may proceed without desorption into the gas phase, thus leveling kinetic differences between the mechanisms of BF and MF formation. With this regard further on we shall consider the generalized kinetics of formates accumulation (Fig. 5 ). Response curve related the sum of formates (Fig. 5a, curve 1) and curve characterizing surface intermediates accumulation in transient kinetic experiment (Fig. 2) are close and correspond to response curve by СO2. Therefore, generalizing data obtained with transient kinetic studies and in situ FTIR, we may conclude that СO2 formation rate is proportional to formates concentration. A simplifies kinetic scheme of dehydrogenation may be represented as follows: • HCOOH+[Z1]↔[HCOO]ads +[H]ads w 1 = k 1 C HCOOH(1− θ 1), w −1 = k −1 θ 1 • [HCOO]ads +[H]ads →CO2 +H2 +[Z1] w 2 = k 2 θ 1 According to this scheme time dependence of formates concentration follows equation: d θ 1 d t = g S L 1 ( w 1 − ( w − 1 + w 2 ) ) Here: θ1 –concentration of formates [HCOO]ads, g–catalyst weight (g); S–specific surface (m2/g), L1 –is the number of sites for formic acid dehydrogenation designated as [Z1]. As we have already mentioned, the rate of formates decomposition (w2) is by an order of magnitude lower than desorption rate ( w − 1 ) . In the first approximation we may neglect the influence of w 2 on the concentration of formates. Assuming that dynamics of response by formates is mostly determined by formic acid adsorption/desorption stages, we have estimated the rate constants for these stages. Numerical analysis has shown that formate response curves, observed after formic acid supplied is stopped (in both dry and vapor containing flows), do not follow exponential dependence, typical for the first order reaction (see insertions on Fig. 4). According to Rogov et al. [31] this is related to the weakening of formates binding with the surface, as coverage degree increases. According to Figs. 4 and 5 the concentration of formates decreases faster in the presence of water vapors. One might assume that it is provided by the growing rate of formates recombination with the adsorbed hydrogen, since concentration of the latter increases due to water dissociation. However, adsorbed water concentration increases gradually, while response to water presence appears immediately after the flow switching. Therefore, we assume that formic acid desorption in water vapor presence occurs like adsorption substitution reaction. This reaction may be written as [XA]+B→[XB]+A (here A, В are the gas phase species, X is the adsorption site)]. Examples of such reactions including those with water participation are described by Rozovskii [32,33]. Reactions are suggested to proceed via intermediate compound [XАВ], in which A binding with adsorption site is weakened in comparison to that in [XA]. This increases the probability of compound decomposition followed by A evolution into the gas phase. Regarding all above mentioned, we assume that desorption rate dependence on water concentration as well as on the degree of surface coverage by formates is of energetic origin. Therefore, we have expressed effective desorption rate constant k −1 as follows: k − 1 = k − 1 0 exp ( Δ Q 1 × f 1 ( θ 1 ) + Δ Q 2 × f 2 ( C H 2 O ) R T ) Here: k − 1 0 is formic acid desorption rate constant at coverage θ 1 and water concentration close to zero, Δ Q 1 is the change of formic acid adsorption heat at coverage degree changes from 0 to 1. Δ Q 2 is the change of formic acid adsorption heat at water concentration growth from 0 to infinity. The calculated values of kinetic parameters of adsorption/desorption, found via FTIR data fitting, are listed in Table 2 . Dependence f 1 ( θ 1 ) is a linear-fractional function: f 1 = θ 1/(2− θ 1) Fig. 6 a demonstrates the heat of НCOOH adsorption versus surface coverage by formates. Let us note that dependence character is similar to that derived from calorimetry data [31]. The effect of formates coverage on the effective desorption constant k −1 is shown in Fig. 6b. The calculated values of coverage θ 1 achieved in these experiments at the time of switching HCOOH+air mixture to the air (or air+H2O) is 0.61 at 120°C and is 0.58 at 140°C. The values of k -1 corresponding to these coverages in a dry flow is 0.8*10−2 (at 120°C) and is 1.1*10−2 (at 140°C), i.e. is more than ten times higher than k −1 0. The addition of 4% H2O into the flow increases the value k −1 by an order of magnitude as compared to those in a dry flow. 3.4 Transient kinetic studies in the closed reactor When 1.7 tor of formic acid are supplied into the closed reactor, one may register CO and water formation (Fig. 7 ), СO2 concentration being too low for registration. The summed concentration of HCOOH+CO decreases with time most likely due to the formic acid adsorption. Taking previous experiments into account, we may assume that formic acid adsorbs mostly as formates. Maximum concentration of formates in this experiment, calculated from the balance ratios, does not exceed 0.35*1018 molecules/m2, which is far less than in the flow reactor experiments. A lower concentration of formates and lower temperature explain CO2 absence among reaction products. As formic acid is supplied onto preliminarily oxidized catalyst, CO accumulation rate (calculated as Δ CO i / Δ t i ) decreases as gas phase formic acid concentration decreases, while formates concentration grows (Fig. 7a). CO response dynamics agrees with the mechanism suggested by Avdeev and Parmon [24], according to which dehydration pathway is initiated by HCOOH adsorption by the oxygen of COH hydroxyl group, followed by the synchronous formation of hydroxylated surface and CO molecules evolution into the gas phase. This path is completed by H2O desorption. Slow water evolution observed in our experiment is also an evidence for this mechanism. Preliminarily water adsorption in amount of 1Torr has no effect on the dynamics of formates accumulation, while CO formation rate decreases by 4-fold (Fig. 7b). Therefore, first of all water block the sites, responsible for formic acid dehydration. According to [34,35] water adsorption on V2O5 depends on the local geometry of the adsorption site. Water adsorbs on saturated plane (010) as a weakly bonded molecular form. In the case of distorted tetrahedron structure (for example, on planes (100), (001) and (101)), both V and O ions are unsaturated, with electron deficiency on vanadium and electron excess on bridging oxygen. These planes show a strong tendency of water adsorption via dissociation, because charge difference may be almost completely neutralized by protons located at the oxygen ions and OH- groups of vanadium ions. In the case of a monolayer V/Ti oxide catalyst, monomer and polymer vanadium particles form on the support surface. Their configuration varies, and their tetrahedron structure is distorted to some extent [36,37]. We think that such structures may have some strongly unsaturated sites V+-O−, which are energetically favorable the strong dissociation adsorption of water. These sites, further on designated as [Z2], most likely show the highest activity at formic acid dehydration. The 4-fold decrease of CO accumulation rate observed in this experiment means, that adsorbing water blocks about 75% of sites [Z2]. Knowing preliminarily adsorbed water amount (1Torr or 0.38*1018 mol/m2), one may estimate the number of these sites. It is 0.5*1018 site/m2. Basing on experiment results, we may represent dehydration kinetic scheme as follows: 3) HCOOH+[Z2]→CO+[Н2О]ads, w 3 = k 3 C HCOOH(1− θ 2) 4) [Н2О]ads ↔H2O+[Z2], w 4 = k 4 θ 2, w-4 = k-4 C H2O(1− θ 2) Here: θ2 is the coverage of sites Z2 by the adsorbed water. Unsteady state kinetic equations, describing CO and H2O gas phase concentrations and adsorbed water concentration in the closed reactor, may be written as: N V d С C O d t = g S L 2 w 3 N V d С H 2 O d t = g S L 2 ( w 4 − w − 4 ) d θ 2 d t = ( w 3 − w 4 + w − 4 ) Starting θ 2 values: θ 2 =0 at the supply onto the oxidized surface, θ 2 =0.75 at the supply after preliminary water adsorption. Fig. 7 shows that suggested model well described experimental results obtained in the closed reactor. For comparison one may look at Fig. 7а with СО concentration dependence, calculated according to the formate mechanism (dotted line). Apparently the latter differs significantly from the experimental curve. Table 3 lists rate constants, obtained via the fitting of experimental dependencies of gas phase concentrations. We have failed to estimate k-4 due to the very low water concentration in the gas phase. Using the suggested dehydration kinetic scheme, we may explain CO transient response dynamics in the flow reactor (see Fig. 2). At the start of experiment, when actually all dehydration sites are free, CO formation rate increases synchronously with formic acid concentration growth. With time free sites concentration decreases dye to the slow desorption of water, and thus dehydration rate starts to fall. 3.5 Kinetic model Therefore, basing on the data on unsteady state kinetic investigations, we may suggest the following generalized scheme of formic acid decomposition on vanadia-titania catalyst (Fig. 8 ): Reaction proceeds via two parallel routes: on one type sites dehydrogenation occurs, yielding CO2 and H2, on the other type sites dehydration goes, giving CO and H2O. In order to verify the suggested mechanism of formic acid dehydrogenation (stages 1, 2) and dehydration (stages 3, 4) we have done numerical analysis of steady state kinetic data (see Table 1). Dehydrogenation : steady state dehydrogenation rate ( W C O 2 ) was expressed as: W C O 2 = L 1 k 2 θ 1 S T , where θ 1 S T was determined via numerical solution of equation: k 1 C C H O O H ( 1 − θ 1 S T ) = k − 1 0 exp ( Δ Q 1 f 1 ( θ 1 ) + Δ Q 2 f 2 ( С H 2 O ) R T ) θ 1 S T + k 2 θ 1 S T Here: Δ Q 1 f 1 ( θ 1 ) and Δ Q 2 f 2 ( С H 2 O ) characterize formic acid adsorption heat dependence on the coverage by formates and water vapor concentration, respectively. On calculation sites number L 1 , function f 1 ( θ 1 ) , as well as value Δ Q 1 were assigned, Function f 2 ( С H 2 O ) , value Δ Q 2 and constants k 1 , k − 1 0 and k 2 were determined via fitting. According to numerical analysis, as in reaction mixture added water concentration attains 10%, formic acid desorption rate constant increases by value corresponding to adsorption heat decrease by 12kJ/mol approximately. Further water concentration growth above 10% has no effect on the rate of formic acid desorption. Thus found function f 2 ( С H 2 O ) looks as follows: f 2 ( С H 2 O ) = С H 2 O С H 2 O + 0.02 Dehydrogenation kinetic parameters (both assigned and found with fitting) are combined in Table 4 . Dehydration : steady state dehydration rate ( W C O ) is equal to: W C O = L 2 k 3 C H C O O H ( 1 − θ 2 S T ) Where θ 2 S T was determined via solution of equation: k3CHCOOH(1-θ2)+ k-4CH2O(1-θ2) = k4θ2 This equation is solved analytically. Therefore, one may express steady state dehydration rate ( W C O ) in explicit form as: W C O = L 2 k 4 k 3 C H C O O H k 4 + k 3 C H C O O H + k − 4 C H 2 O Values of constants k 3, k 4 and k -4, found via steady state data fitting (at a given L2), are also given in Table 4. Fig. 9 shows simulation results. Apparently, the calculated dependencies of reaction rate via both routs (dehydrogenation and dehydration) on water concentration are in a good agreement with experimental data. Let us note that rate constants k 1 and k − 1 0 given in Table 4 are close to estimates obtained earlier from in situ FTIR data (Table 2). Approximating temperature dependence of k 3 and k 4 from Table 4 to T=115°C, we obtain a good agreement with simulation of experiments in the closed reactor (Table 3). Such coincidence of constants estimates obtained from independent experiments gives additional evidence for suggested kinetic model correctness. Under studied conditions rate determining stages are: via dehydrogenation route – formates decomposition (step 2) with activation energy equal to 60kJ/mol, via dehydration route – water desorption (step 4) with activation energy equal to 100kJ/mol. Higher activation energy of step 4 in comparison to that of step 2 causes CO selectivity increase at reaction temperature growth. 4 Conclusion Unsteady and steady kinetic methods and in situ FTIR have been used to study formic acid decomposition on V/Ti oxide catalyst. Reaction is found to proceed via two routes: dehydration and dehydrogenation. During dehydrogenation formate complexes are accumulated on the catalyst surface, which may either recombine with protons and desorb as formic acid or decompose to CO2. Dehydrogenation site is a vanadyl group, in which oxygen accepts the proton, while vanadium cation stabilizes the formate ion. Sites for formates stabilization appear to be non uniform, since acid adsorption heat decreases with the growing coverage. In the presence of water vapor adsorbed formates are substituted by water. Therefore, formic acid desorption is accelerated, and thus formates decomposition to CO2 is decelerated. Dehydration does not proceed via the formate mechanism. As strongly unsaturated sites V+-O− interact with HCOOH, there occurs a synchronous cleavage of the COH and CH bonds. Meanwhile two hydroxyl groups are formed, and CO molecule are evolved into the gas phase. Recombination of hydroxyl groups generates the adsorbed water. This path is completed by water desorption into the gas phase. As water vapors are added into reaction mixture, active dehydration sites are blocked with the adsorbing water, yielding a dramatic decrease of CO steady state formation rate. coredata.dc:description: A detailed kinetic model for formic acid (HCOOH) decomposition on oxide vanadium-titanium (7.3%V2O5/92.7%TiO2) catalyst has been developed based on transient kinetic studies and IR spectroscopy in situ. Formic acid decomposition to CO2 (dehydrogenation) and to CO (dehydration) proceeds via different mechanistic routes. Dehydrogenation proceeds via the conventional “formate” mechanism and include reversible dissociative adsorption of formic acid on vanadyl group V=O. The oxygen of the group acts as a proton acceptor whereas a vanadium cation is a formate anion stabilizer. Formate complexes can recombinate with protons and desorb in the form of formic acid or decompose to CO2. Dehydration reaction follows a different mechanism. An interaction of the coordination unsaturated sites V+-O− with HCOOH leads to the synchronous cleavage of the COH and CH bonds. Meanwhile the two OH hydroxyl groups are formed and CO molecule is evolved into gas phase. The path is completed by water desorption. The rate constants and activation energies of elementary steps are calculated for a dehydrogenation and dehydration reactions. The rate-limited steps of the reaction are formate decomposition stage for dehydrogenation path (Ea =60kJ/mol) and water desorption stage for dehydration rout (Ea =100kJ/mol). The difference in the values of activation energies results in an increase of selectivity towards CO with reaction temperature elevation. Water inhibits formic acid decomposition. In the case the dehydrogenation, it connected with adsorption displacement of formates with water, whereas, in the case of dehydration, it is associated with an active centers blocking by adsorbed water. The developed kinetic model takes into account the water effect of both routs and satisfactorily describes the steady state reaction behavior.
coredata.dc:title: Formic acid decomposition over V-Ti oxide catalyst: Mechanism and kinetics
